div.p: NEVVS CERTAIN AND TERRIBLE FROM THE KINGDOM OF POLAND, BEING The Copie of a Letter, ſent by Jerome Nicholas to a friend of his, dwelling at Graveſend.
Relating how the Turke hath paſt the Confines of the Kingdom, with an almoſt invincible Army: and what barbarity they uſe towards Chriſtians in thoſe parts, having gotten the upper hand.
div.q: Nunc tua res agitur paries dum proxim •• ardet.

div.p:
REceiving from you Letters at all occaſions, wherein you certifie me how all matters go in England, it ſhould be a very unkind part in me, not to write backe ſomething to you, although it did concern you nothing; yet that which I write to you now concerns not you onely, but alſo everie good Chriſtian. Know therefore good Sir, that upon the twentieth ſixth day of January, the great Turke having ever in his heart a grudge againſt the Polanders, for ancient quarrels, determining now alſo to be revenged, when a great part of his Forces are imployed elſewhere, gathered together above fourtie thouſand of his moſt expert Souldiers, being to the number of eighteen thouſand Janizaries, in whom conſiſteth his chief ſtrength, and two and twentie thouſand Timariots, which are horſemen lightly armed, for the moſt part, imployed in forraging, and in pillaging
of the Countrey, where the Turke doth maintain any warre, theſe paſſed on above fourteen Leagues in the Countrey, making havocke of the poore people all the way as they went, ſparing neither young nor old rich nor poore, but ſweeping all away with a moſt bloodie maſſacre: uſing alſo extraordinarie torments to thoſe that would not immediately abjure the Chriſtian Religion, binding them to poſts, and then circumciſing them▪ At
• runſtad a little Village neer to our Citie, the Lieutenant Generall with five thouſand horſemen, gave the Timariots battell, which was upon the twentie eight day of January laſt paſt, but being oppreſt with their number, he was forced to flie, having loſt but a few of his men, leaving all the ground beſtrewed with the dead bodies of the Turkiſh horſemen; Having himſelf alſo received one dangerous wound in the right ſide, with a Launce, but we hope he will ſhortly recover; for the reſt of his wounds are nothing ſo dangerous. And indeed if he did not, we ſhould find great want of him; for to ſpeak the truth, he is an excellent man, and verie expert in all manner of Militarie Diſcipline, and in many Battels fought againſt the Turke he hath
approved himſelfe very valiant to his King and Countrey.

But to returne to the Turkiſh Armie, they being proud of this deare bought victory, and vowing ſharpe revenge, marcht ſtill on towards the Citie in which wee now remaine, killing every one that had not fled to the next Towne, with extreame tortures; it being thought a ſport amongſt the Turks, to rip up womens bellies with their Scimitaries, and to carrie young children upon the top of their Launces, ſpringing with bloud. They have approached our Citie, and lie verie neere to it ſtrongly entrenched, and have planted five Canon and ſix Demi-Canon againſt the walls of the Citie, and they threw every houre over our walls hot burning Granadoes, which (bleſt be God) by reaſon of our watchfulneſſe and care, doe no great harme; onely a woman as ſhee was paſſi • g the ſtreete, with her childe in her armes, both ſhee and the poore infant were killed by the unhappie fall of a Granadoe.

Wee kill every day both with ſmall ſhot and great, huge numbers of that unhallowed packe, eſpecially at their laſt aſſault; where by reaſonable computation, there was found to have dyed
a thouſand in leſſe than three houres. Out Towne is very ſtrong, God be praiſed, and our Souldiers are couragious enough, eſpecially the Inhabitants, as they have beſt reaſon, they being ſure to looſe their houſes and fortunes, (if the Towne be taken) if not their lives withall. Out Towne hath endured the Siege at leaſt twenty-two dayes now, and our walls are mightily battered, I beſeech God to ſend us ſpeedy and ſtrong ſuccour, and let us rather have any miſchance, than to fall into the hands of thoſe cruell and ſavage people. For our Governour hath beene divers times called to a parlie with their Captaine, and had articles delivered to him, to which agreeing he ſhould yeeld the Towne. But having ſhewed them the Souldiers and Townſmen, they all drew their ſwords, and ſwore they would rather die than accept of any ſuch conditions.

The Articles are theſe;
Firſt, That every one of the Townſmen and Souldiers, ſhould deliver up their weapons and ammunition and victualling.
Secondly, That they ſhould goe out of the Citie with ropes about their necks, and their hands bound behind them, in token of ſubmiſſion, all except the Governour.
Thirdly, That they ſhould leave their wives and children and goods behind them: and carry nothing with them but one ſuite of clothes, and one paire of ſhooes with them.
Fourthly, That they ſhould ſweare by Mahomet never to ſerve the King againe.
Fifthly, That they ſhould all be markt in the forehead.
Theſe are the Articles; The bearer is in great haſte, being in danger to be ſurpriſed by the Turkes Scouts, if he ſtay till breake of day.
Farewell; Remember mee to my wife and children, tell them that I am in health; but by no means relate to her in what danger I am in; ſo committing you to God, I reſt

closer.signed: Your moſt obſequious friend, IEROME NICHOLAS.
